discussion.content: IMO the correct answer is: E

comments.content: A, sorry, UA is not SA

questions.question_text:
You are configuring access rules in a Session Border Controller Peering architecture.
Which configuration step is required to allow access from any User Agent (UA)?

choices.E: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to agents-only.
choices.D: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the ip-address parameter to the IP subnet of your trusted User Agent (UA).
choices.B: Navigate to the realm-config configuration element and set the addr-prefix parameter to the IP subnet of your trusted User Agent (UA).
choices.C: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to address-prefix.
choices.A: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to all.

comments.content: default value means 1 value, there can't be 2 default values, and here there aren't any. D is correct

choices.A: The default community strings are acme and packet.
choices.C: Community strings are in passive mode.
choices.E: Only one trap receiver can be configured.
choices.D: There are no default community strings.
choices.B: The default community strings are public and private.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true when SNMP access is enabled to the Session Border Controller?

discussion.content: C, pide que haga match en el URI request, lo cual implica desde donde llega, la D no es correcta, en tal caso seria to-address ya que destination-address no existe en local-policy

choices.A: Navigate to the policy-attribute configuration element and configure the from-address parameter to match the Request-URI value.
choices.B: Navigate to the policy-attribute configuration element and configure the to-address parameter to match the Request-URI value.
choices.D: Navigate to the local-policy configuration element and configure the to-address parameter to match the Request-URI value.
choices.C: Navigate to the local-policy configuration element and configure the from-address parameter to match the Request-URI value.
choices.E: Navigate to the local-policy configuration element and configure the destination-address parameter to match the Request-URI value.

questions.question_text: Which configuration step is required to route a SIP call based on the value of the SIP INVITE Request-URI?

discussion.content: access-control is under session-router, not media-manager. Correct answer should be AC

questions.question_text:
You are adding peers to a Policy-Based Realm Bridging (PBRB) configuration.
Which two configuration steps, among others, are required? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Navigate to the session-router configuration branch and configure the sip-nat configuration element.
choices.B: Navigate to the session-router configuration branch and configure the sipd-address configuration element.
choices.E: Navigate to the media-manager configuration branch and configure the access-control configuration element.
choices.C: Navigate to the session-router configuration branch and configure the local-policy configuration element.
choices.A: Navigate to the media-manager configuration branch and configure the realm-config configuration element.

discussion.content:
B and D (not E).
NAT is a stateful session, therefore must be established first in order to permit returning traffic (if not, it will be considered unsolicited traffic and so discarded).

questions.question_text: What two problems do Network Address Translations (NATs) introduce into VoIP networks? (Choose two.)

choices.B: NATs block unsolicited incoming signaling and media.
choices.C: NATs block unsolicited incoming signaling but allow incoming media.
choices.E: NATs devices can be overloaded by incoming registrations.
choices.A: There are no major concerns with NATs.
choices.D: NATs pinholes expire after a configurable time.
